title: He Filmed Your Favorite Skate Videos: The Jon Miner Story | Let It Kill You
description:
If you were a skateboarder in the early 2000s, chances are you grew up on Jon Miner’s work. The visionary behind iconic projects like This is Skateboarding, Kids in Emerica, Stay Gold, and more, Miner helped define a generation of skate videos. Skaters couldn’t get enough of his signature look and feel — raw, stylish, unforgettable.

To kick off Season 2 of Let It Kill You, series creator Ben McQueen heads to Santa Rosa to dive into Jon’s personal life, tracing his journey through stories, memories, and candid moments. Jon gets real — personal, vulnerable, and unfiltered — opening up about skateboarding, life, and what it takes to be one of the best skateboarders to ever step behind the camera.

From Andrew Reynolds to Heath Kirchart, hear from the legends themselves as they reflect on what made working with Jon so special.

Subscribe to VICE and get exclusive early access to our documentaries, as well as 4 issues of the recently revived VICE magazine each year: https://www.vice.com/en/youtubemembership/

title: Escaping the FLDS cult
description:
The FLDS broke away from mainstream Mormonism in order to continue the practice of polygamy. They established the community of Short Creek along the Utah/Arizona border to follow their beliefs in isolation. 

In 2011, their prophet Warren Jeffs was sentenced to life in prison (plus 20 years) for abuse of two of his child brides, ages 12 and 15.

In 2016, VICE travelled to Short Creek to meet with some of the young women who escaped from the cult, but returned to Short Creek to try and rebuild a new life there. Watch the full video on @VICE.

title: The 'Tan Mom' origin story
description:
In this episode of Fameish, we’re reintroduced to Patricia Krentcil, aka ‘Tan Mom’. 

Patricia became a viral phenomenon in 2012 after being falsely accused of bringing her five-year-old daughter into a tanning salon. The media attention and public scrutiny that ensued was as incessant as it was vicious. Watch the full video on @VICE.

title: Nobody knew 'Never Gonna Give You Up' was going to be a hit. Besides Rick Astley.
description:
Nearly everyone has been RickRoll’d. But few know the real story of the artist behind the 1987 hit “Never Gonna Give You Up” nor do they know about the mysterious origins of the viral RickRoll video meme that exploded in the mid-2000s. 

VICE meets Rick Astley and the creators of the song to learn about Rick’s meteoric rise to fame, sudden retirement, and surprising comeback. We also meet the creator of the popular RickRoll meme that cemented this persistent hit for generations to come.

title: This honey makes people hallucinate
description:
Nepal’s Gurung people live mostly in small villages in the vast Annapurna mountain ranges. In this remote region, they practice an ancient tradition of honey hunting where they descend towering cliffs on handmade ladders, to harvest honey nestled under jagged overhangs. 

In spring, the Gurung’s honey contains a rare substance called grayanotoxin from rhododendron flowers that’s known for its intoxicating effects. While some accounts say it’s a deadly poison, others refer to it as an aphrodisiac, powerful medicine, and a hallucinogenic drug. 

In 2016, VICE travelled deep into the Annapurna mountains to join a Gurung village on their spring hunt and understand Mad Honey's effects. Watch the full video on @VICE.

title: Inside the Pagans and Sutar Soldiers rivalry
description:
In the spring of 2019, former Pagan member Troy Harris was out at a bar with his wife when he was ambushed by several Pagans.

Before the attack, Harris had left the Pagans to join their rivals, the Sutar Soldiers, where he was appointed Vice President.

description:

title: C-O-M-E to the Mermaid Parade and you'll run into some of NYC's most creative characters
description:
For over 40 years, New York's most creative characters have been gathering in Coney Island to participate in the Mermaid Parade. There's no ethnic, religious, or political connection between participants, but locals call it the official opening of summer in the city.  

In this episode of GATHERINGS, VICE host Jackson Garrett hitches a ride to Coney Island to find out what NYC's oddest tradition means to those who celebrate it.

title: Cleaning old gravestones, and sharing stories about the people who lie underneath them
description:
We meet Caitlin Abrams, who has gone viral for cleaning old gravestones and sharing stories about the lives and deaths of the people who lie underneath them.

From the woman said to be a vampire, to a young couple who perished just before their wedding day, Caitlin tells the stories of people who died hundreds of years ago, as she works to restore their final resting place. 

Using the Internet, she has researched the best methods to bring a gravestone back to life, and she’s inspiring followers on TikTok to do the same.

title: Asking rappers why they sip lean
description:
Lean is often made by mixing prescription-strength codeine cough syrup with soda. The drink has become popularized in hip-hop culture over the last several years, with famous rappers drinking and featuring it in their music videos. Now the trend has spread to social media, making it even more popular among fans who are posting to emulate some of their favorite rap stars.

VICE’s Matt Shea travels to Florida to meet some users and distributors of lean to see its influence on pop culture first-hand. Watch the full video on @VICE.

title: Smoking weed in the name of God
description:
In Nepal, cannabis isn’t just a plant—it’s sacred. Every year during Shiva Ratri, over a million devotees gather to honor Shiva, the god of creation, by lighting up at Kathmandu’s holiest temple. But outside of this one day a year, cannabis remains illegal—a law rooted in the US-led War on Drugs, which pressured Nepal to abandon its ancient traditions in the 1970s.

Watch the full video on @VICE.

title: "My dad has 14 wives..."
description:
Although the mainstream Mormon church abandoned polygamy over 100 years ago, many splinter groups across Utah still practice plural marriage. One such group is the Kingston Clan, known to members as The Order. The Kingstons live in Salt Lake City and run their religion like a secretive business empire. Watch the full video on @VICE.
